item.title: The true jump method
item.description: A while ago, I learned a numerical recipe for simulating state-dependent jump processes from this paper by Romain Veltz. item.title: Stochastic limits, part 2: tails, memory, and the Joseph and Noah effects
item.description: In the last post, we discussed what happens to the sum \[\begin{equation} \lim_{N\to\infty} S_N - \mu N, \qquad S_N := \sum_{i=1}^{N} X_i, \end{equation}\] with \(X_i\) drawn from some “nice” distribution with \(\mu := \mathbb{E}[X_i]\). item.title: Stochastic limits, part 1: CLT, Donsker’s FCLT
item.description: In the ever-growing list of talks I’ve suffered through, I’ve noticed a bizarre trend in many given by mathematicians considered “rockstars”: half the talk consists of rambling about old, obscure books in their field. I’m honestly not sure if this is simply because they can get away with it because they’re already famous, or because arcane tomes are a genuinely good source of information. I’m operating under the latter assumption.
